section.name: Welcome to Jacclog
section.p: Jacclog is a software project management and comprehension tool. Based on the concept of a project object model (POM), Jacclog can manage a project's build, reporting and documentation from a central piece of information.

If you think that Jacclog could help your project, you can find out more information about in the "About Jacclog" section of the navigation. This includes an in-depth description of what Jacclog is , a list of some of its main features , and a set of frequently asked questions about what Jacclog is
.
This site is separated into the following sections, depending on how you'd like to use Jacclog:

li.span: Information for those needing to build a project that uses Jacclog
Information for those wanting to use Jacclog to build their project, including a "10 minute test" that gives a practical overview of Jacclog's main features in just 10 minutes
Information for those who may or may not be using Jacclog, but want to provide a plugin for shared functionality or to accompany their own product or toolset
Information for those who may or may not use, but are interested in getting project metadata into the repository
Information for those who are currently developers, or who are interested in contributing to the Jacclog project itself

section.p: Each guide is divided into a number of trails to get you started on a particular topic, and includes a reference area and a "cookbook" of common examples.
You can access the guides at any time from the left navigation.
If you are looking for a quick reference, you can use the documentation index.
Support for Jacclog is available in a variety of different forms.
To get started, search the documentation, the wiki , issue tracker , or the mailing list archives to see if the problem has been solved or reported before.

If the problem has not been reported before, the recommended way to get help is to subscribe to the Jacclog Users Mailing list . Many other users and Jacclog developers will answer your questions there, and the answer will be archived for others in the future.
Jacclog is an open source community and welcomes contributions. If you'd like to get involved, see the Guide to helping with Jacclog.
